title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act titled "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" requires drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under State TANF programs. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under State TANF programs, requiring states to operate an illegal drug use screening and testing program. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under State TANF programs, including testing individuals at high risk of substance abuse and potentially continuing testing at random intervals. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under State programs funded under this part for illegal drug use, with denial of assistance for individuals not screened or tested. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals seeking assistance under State programs, with denial of aid for those not screened or tested for illegal drug use. Screening is done through an effective survey method to identify potential substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening for individuals seeking assistance under State programs, using an effective survey method to identify potential substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening for individuals receiving assistance under State programs to identify potential substance abuse and require testing for illegal drug use if deemed at high risk. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening for individuals receiving assistance to identify substance abuse risk and test for illegal drug use if deemed high risk. The term 'illegal drug' refers to controlled substances defined in the Controlled Substances Act. If assistance is denied, the State must continue providing assistance to other family members. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening for aid recipients to detect substance abuse risk and test for illegal drug use if deemed high risk. If an individual is denied assistance, the State must continue providing aid to other family members. Amendments made by this section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter that begins on or after 1 year after the enactment of the Act. If a State plan requires legislation to meet the new requirements, it will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting them before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the close of the 1st regular session. The State plan will not be considered non-compliant with new requirements solely for not meeting them before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature.
